HIGHLANDS INSTALLS NEEDLEPOINT BIPOLAR IONIZATION SYSTEMS TO IMPROVE INDOOR AIR QUALITY

Utilizing funds from the CARES Act, the Highlands School District, with the help of Tudi Mechanical, recently completed the installation of Global Plasma Solutions Needlepoint Bipolar Ionization Technology systems in all Highlands school buildings as an important health and safety measure to improve indoor air quality. The ionization systems deliver cleaner, safer air without producing ozone or other harmful byproducts. The systems destroy pathogens (bacteria and viruses), minimizing the cross-contamination of germs between students and staff.

Check out the short video clip below to learn more about the needlepoint bipolar ionization technology installed in our schools!

SUMMER LITERACY KITS DISTRIBUTED TOMORROW!

Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, we were not able to hold our in-person Title I Summer School this year. However, we have purchased summer literacy kits for all students who were in grades K-4 last year so that they can continue practicing their reading and math skills. Each kit has three books, a student journal, a math skills packet and a summer reading log.

Families are able to pick up these packets at Highlands Elementary School tomorrow, Tuesday, July 21. Distribution for Kindergarten through 2nd grade will be from 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. Grades 3 and 4 can pick up between 1:00 p.m. to 3:00 p.m. If you have children in multiple grades, you can choose either time to pick up. Please come to the main entrance of the elementary school. We look forward to seeing you.

The Building Block of Natrona
June 3 at 2:59 PM ¬∑

Natrona Summer Youth Breakfast & Lunch Program

Starts on Monday, June 8!

Free meals will be distributed "grab-and-go" style this summer at Natrona Community Park to all local youth. Meals will be distributed each weekday (Mon-Fri) at the park from 10:30-11:30 am.

No registration is required but please text, email or FB message us to let us know how many kids you'll need meals for this summer (this helps us order enough). Note: If you've already provided this information during the school lunch program, you do not need to message us again.

Adults or youth may pick up the meals - we'll be providing breakfast & lunch at the same time.

You may take meals for all of the youth in your family when you pick up.

We are doing the grab-and-go distribution due to ongoing health concerns related to the COVID-19 pandemic. All volunteers will be wearing gloves and masks.

The program is scheduled to run from June 8 through July 24.

This is a PA Department of Education & USDA program, sponsored locally by the United Methodist Church Union and hosted by The Building Block of Natrona.

HMS STUDENTS SUCCEED IN MATH COMPETITION: Highlands Middle School Gifted and Talented Education (GATE) students in grades 5-8 were members of the Allegheny County school teams that took 1st Place in a two-week online Math Competition for the strategy game, 24.

The goal of 24 is to take 4 given numbers and add, subtract, multiple and/or divide to get the answer 24. Placed in teams against other schools in Allegheny County, our GATE students were on the 1st Place winning teams of their grade division. In addition, 8th grader Jocelyn Bielak won 2nd Place among all of the 8th grade students who competed.

Highlands GATE teacher Mrs. Rebecca Mentecky was proud of their accomplishments. "We have some awesome students at our Middle School," she said.

"HOME" MADE ART: HHS ART STUDENTS GET CREATIVE
Check out some of the artwork that Highlands High School students are making while learning from home! They have used watercolors, coffee grounds as a paint medium, home items to create color wheels. The students are finding inspiration in everyday objects, such as popsicle sticks and scraps of paper to works of art made of natural materials from their own back yards. Their art teacher, Mrs. Renae Yoder, is proud of their efforts. "Learning art through the computer has not been easy, but our students have really stepped up and have expanded their creativity," she said.
